s.text: Further, he waits until Page 348, upon learning that Revlon had withdrawn its offer of a job for Monica, to go all Sally Fields on us and exclaim, "What do you know?
[Click to read Isikoff's doubts about whether he should have used Tripp as a source, from Pages 356-57.

When, not if, the next Linda Tripp comes to me with an amazing story that I know in my heart and gut is true, I will simply bypass the agonizing mainstream media, the doubting Thomases and whiners, and go directly to Matt Drudge.
All along, Michael Isikoff was a player in this story, and he has written a player's book.
It is not sporting of Spikey to dump on his source to provide cover for his own deep activity as a deep player in this drama.
All along, Michael Isikoff was a player in this story, and he has written a player's book.

Editor's Note: Michael Isikoff's Uncovering Clinton recounts the events of Flytrap from the perspective of a reporter who in investigating the story became a key player in it, since news that his article might appear in Newsweek precipitated Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr's hurried investigation into President Clinton's dalliance with Monica Lewinsky.
This being a book by a player, we asked another player to review it.
All along, Michael Isikoff was a player in this story, and he has written a player's book.
This being a book by a player, we asked another player to review it.
It is not sporting of Spikey to dump on his source to provide cover for his own deep activity as a deep player in this drama.
All along, Michael Isikoff was a player in this story, and he has written a player's book.

Editor's Note: Michael Isikoff's Uncovering Clinton recounts the events of Flytrap from the perspective of a reporter who in investigating the story became a key player in it, since news that his article might appear in Newsweek precipitated Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr's hurried investigation into President Clinton's dalliance with Monica Lewinsky.
This being a book by a player, we asked another player to review it.
Note to the Irony Police: Linda never gave me a word on paper regarding Monica and I am at this moment reviewing Michael Isikoff's "big-bucks book."
Throughout this enthralling tale, one feels a "please don't hit me" cringe coming from the author.
In those items a name I had all but forgotten cropped up again: Linda R. Tripp.
He is particularly savage to the woman the media love to hate (a cheap and easy shot in order to provide the book with a villain).
She is an easy target.
Subsequently, she had withdrawn the project and we parted company, a common occurrence in the publishing business.
Note to the Irony Police: Linda never gave me a word on paper regarding Monica and I am at this moment reviewing Michael Isikoff's "big-bucks book."
All along, Michael Isikoff was a player in this story, and he has written a player's book.
